I married my first husband out of the need to be included.  To be a couple, to be part of his "unit of friends", to experience the fun and adventure they all shared. I regret that I didn’t break off my relationship with my fiancé the first time I caught him lying to me (which was within the first month of our relationship) instead of four years later, especially because he invariably ended up lying about lying to me.  

Because he was so codependent and enmeshed with his family of origin and adult daughters, his need to keep everyone pleased meant that his lies were always about stupid stuff that no one would ever need to lie about.  Regardless, his lying and hiding meant that I could never trust him about anything.  Every single lie caused significant damage to our relationship. 

At least I didn’t marry him.  I know I dodged a bullet; and, because I am learning how to value myself, I won’t let anyone treat me like that again. I now have a zero-tolerance policy for being lied to.
I was too wrapped up with a recent breakup to consider a embarking on a relationship with a women who turned out to be even more amazing later in life.  The table was set and I failed to see it.

regretList.regret: When I was 17 I 'dropped' a good friend - not deliberately (in fact, I didn't even realise I'd done it until long, long afterwards) - but through thoughtlessness.  My home life was miserable and unhappy and entirely without guidance, and from around the age of ten I'd spent a lot of time with this friend, usually at her house.  At 17 I met a boy and just became utterly consumed by him.  I stopped seeing my friend overnight.  I can see now (over forty years later) why I was so lacking in awareness, and have a lot of compassion for my 17 year old self, but still wish our friendship had not ended because of my utter thoughtlessness, and haven't really forgiven myself.

regretList.regret: I regret not pursuing a better paid career. I regret falling for the "follow your passion" mantra without realising how much hardship this philosophy would bring. If I could go back, I would pick a university subject that was more geared towards leading people into a realistic prospect of earning comfortable money. Possibly, I might not have even have pursued further studies at all as a lot of careers don't strictly require a formal qualification. Had I been given the benefit of regained time, I would have also invested my mind to formulating a business plan, seeing what the skills shortages were/are, what my set of skills can bring to society rather than working for a means of self satisfaction and self indulgence.

I truly don't have any regret. My life was fully shaped by circumstances beyond my control. I was sent to the United States alone at age six as part of Operation Peter Pan. I was not reunited with my parents until three years later. When we reunited the bond was irreparably broken. Everything that followed is a series of events that influenced every aspect of my life. Some for better, many for worst. On the surface, I exceeded expectations. But deep down, my problems stem from trying to assimilate and walk the line between cultures.

My significant regret is that as a woman, I was given second class treatment and development as I grew up.  I regret that my mother smoked/drank during her pregnancy with me. I regret that in the early fifties, MDs did not treat "lazy eye" amblyopia well and the impact that has on learning. I regret that my siblings were competitive and not supportive of me. I regret that it wasn't until I was 38 years old that I self-diagnosed my ADD through reading a NYT magazine article. I regret that scientific research hasn't been done traditionally for women. I regret that it wasn't until I was 69 that I found bioidentical hormone replacement. I could have done so much more with my life! I would have liked to helped others more, from what I learned.

For me it's a bit hard to say. For one hand I don't believe so much in the concept of regret. I like to think that every choice I made over the years are in a way responsible for who I'm today and I'm mostly proud of myself. So silly regrets like not learning a third language? Yes, but maybe "regret" is a strong word for that feeling. But in the end, wouldn't call it a regret itself but a wish. A wish to live life. I think although regret is a concept I don't fully "believe", is one that pushes me forward. The fear of regrets is more than a fuel than the regret itself. By the end I know I won't regret. I know that I'll do my best. As this idea, the need to avoid the regret, will keep me in line.

When my friend was dying, I waited too long to go see him one last time, because I was afraid of missing a work meeting.  I went the next day, and during a layover on my flight, I had a voicemail saying he had just died.  He died while I was on the plane, if I had just gone the day before I would have had a chance to see him and say "good bye" in person. I was 33 when he died, and he was 76.  I was too young to understand that when someone is dying, you go see them, you can't wait.  Throughout our friendship it was always me that cancelled plans so I could go on a date or hang out with my friends.  I'm sure he understood, but I don't think I gave our friendship as much respect as he did, but he was very, very important to me and I still cry when I think about missing his last hours even though it was 15 years ago.
